section.hand:
To my L. T
re
r N
o
3 1591.

addressleaf.section:
Belgia 1591 3 Novem
b
To my L. Trea
s

page.lettertext:
May it please yo
r
good L. to be advertised,
at wheras I was willed
by yo
r
letters of
e 23 of Fe
b
last, to recommend unto the
States
e suite of certaine poore creditors of the towne of
Flushing,
to whom
e companies of Cap
t
Wingfield
and of
Randolphe
were indebted,
because as I have formerly signified, I had lerned
at some good po
r
tion
of the saide debtes was discharged already by
e Magistrats of
Flushing, I tooke some time to enquire underhand
e particular
summes, aswell of
at w
ch
was first owing, as of
at which was disbo
r
sed
by
e towne, and also of the residue
at is left as yet unpaied. For
I stoode in some doubt, lest the totall summe had bin demanded of her
High
nes
. Howbeit I finde
at
e whole debt at the first was 892
li
5
sh
11
d
The summe of
at which was required of her Ma
tie
687
li
6
sh
so that there was discharged of the debt 205
li
5
sh
5
d
w
ch
is not
demaunded. Wherupon understanding
at
e Deputies of Flushing had
obtened letters of her Hig
nes
to
e Generall States for
e paiment of
e remainder, I moved them to come in conference w
t
me,
at we might
joine in one suite unto
e States: w
ch
was differred till nowe of late
for divers occasions
at staied theire comming. The states have
alleaged many reasons, to putte
e paim
t
from themselves: w
ch
I have
endevoured to answear, w
t
as muche to the contrary, as I could thinke
upon. But yet to say truly to yo
r
L. these affaires were so con-
fusedly handled in
e
L. of Leicesters
time, as I cannot by any
meanes boult out, by whome
e forsaide debt ought of right to be paied. I
urged them at first to take some ord
r
for discharge of
e whole debt:
but plainely perceaving that I laboured in vaine, according to
at w
ch
yo
r
L. had willed me in yo
r
forsaide letter, I moved them to condiscend
to
e paiment of some good portion, puttinge them in hope,
at
e
LL.
of her Ma
ties
Councell
would be moved in compassion, to induce her
Hig
nes
to doe somew
at
in like manno
r
for
e relief of
e parties. Heer
upon they agreed among them selves to send unto the Provinces about
it: w
ch
beinge done more then once hath caused a long delay: but so
notw
th
standing as at lenght they have resolved to pay
e one halfe of
at
w
ch
is dewe, upon condition that her Ma
tie
will vouch safe to satsifye
e remainder. To this effect they have moved me to write in their
behalfe, and to signifie the povertie and want of the poor widdowes
w
ch
are the creditors and to beseeche her Ma
tie
to pitie their
estate.
&c./
